title: 112_hr1281
content: The Act titled "Restoring Economic Certainty Act of 2011" imposes a moratorium on federal agencies from making rulemaking actions unless an exception is provided. Additionally, it includes requirements regarding economic impact statements. The "Restoring Economic Certainty Act of 2011" mandates that Federal agencies prepare economic impact statements for pending rulemaking actions within 30 days of enactment. After the moratorium period, all rulemaking actions must include an economic impact statement certified by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The "Restoring Economic Certainty Act of 2011" requires Federal agencies to provide an economic impact statement for rulemaking actions, certified by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, detailing the costs, benefits, and employment impact of the regulation. SEC. 4 of the "Restoring Economic Certainty Act of 2011" extends deadlines for actions dependent on rulemaking actions during the moratorium period by 5 months or until the end of the moratorium period. The term "deadline" refers to any specific date for fulfilling obligations under Federal statutes, regulations, or court orders. The President must identify and publish a list of postponed deadlines within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Emergency Exception allows a Federal agency head to request a waiver from rulemaking actions in cases of imminent threats to health or safety, enforcement of criminal laws, or other emergencies. The waiver must be approved by the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs and published in the Federal Register. The Civil Rights Exception exempts rulemaking actions from certain anti-discrimination laws, except those involving quotas or preferences based on age, race, religion, gender, national origin, or disability status. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "Federal agency" in this Act refers to various government entities in the executive branch, excluding specific agencies like the General Accounting Office and the Federal Election Commission. The term "moratorium period" in this Act refers to a two-year period starting 30 days after the enactment of the Act. A "regulation or rule" is defined as an agency statement with future effect that implements, interprets, or prescribes law or policy. Exceptions to the term "regulation or rule" include military or foreign affairs regulations, agency organization rules, and regulations certified by the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs. Management and Budget certifies in writing are limited to repealing existing regulations or rules, particularly those related to aviation safety, granting licenses, registrations, exemptions, variances, relief from regulatory requirements, and actions necessary for technological advancements or the use of substances or products. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to rulemaking actions, licenses, and imminent threats to health or safety. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON CIVIL ACTIONS. No private right of action against a Federal agency for violating this Act. This does not affect other available private rights of action under different laws.
